title-group.article-title: The Use of Multimedia Consent Programs for Surgical Procedures
title-group.subtitle: A Systematic Review

author-notes.corresp: Sanjay Purkayastha, Division of Surgery, Department of Surgery & Cancer, Imperial College London, St Mary’s Hospital Campus, Praed Street, London W2 1NY, UK Email: s.purkayastha@imperial.ac.uk

abstract.p: Objective. To compare multimedia and standard consent, in respect to patient comprehension, anxiety, and satisfaction, for various surgical/interventional procedures. Data sources. Electronic searches of PubMed, MEDLINE, Ovid, Embase, and Google Scholar were performed. Relevant articles were assessed by 2 independent reviewers. Study selection. Comparative (randomized and nonrandomized control trials) studies of multimedia and standard consent for a variety of surgical/interventional procedures were included. Studies had to report on at least one of the outcome measures. Data extraction. Studies were reviewed by 2 independent investigators. The first investigator extracted all relevant data, and consensus of each extraction was performed by a second investigator to verify the data. Conclusion. Overall, this review suggests that the use of multimedia as an adjunct to conventional consent appears to improve patient comprehension. Multimedia leads to high patient satisfaction in terms of feasibility, ease of use, and availability of information. There is no conclusive evidence demonstrating a significant reduction in preoperative anxiety.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Obtaining informed consent is a fundamental step in the surgical pathway and has remained largely unchanged since the term informed consent was first coined in 1957.1 However, this step is becoming increasingly demanding because of the complexity of many modern procedures, as well as increasing time pressures on surgical staff. In addition to this, the modern patient has increased access to information via the Internet and may, therefore, demand more detailed information. A change in focus to a more patient-centered health care system has also placed greater emphasis on effective doctor–patient communication and transfer of information, which is central to the consent process.

Informed consent is defined as “voluntary authorisation by a patient or research participant, with full comprehension of the risks involved for diagnostic or investigative procedures and for medical and surgical treatment.”2(p141) Informed consent may be implied or expressed. Where implied, it reflects positive patient action (eg, voluntary exposure for examination), whereas expressed consent is verbal or written.

Despite the importance of this step in the surgical pathway, surgeons and patients are often poorly prepared for this process. There is no formal training in consent practices and the taking of consent can often be left to a member of the junior surgical staff under significant time pressures on the morning of surgery. This can lead to poor communication and poor transfer of information from the surgeon to the patient. This has important effects on outcomes as well-informed patients tend to have more realistic expectations, higher satisfaction, and improved treatment compliance.3 It is also important to note that the majority of medical malpractice claims are because of failures in communication as opposed to failures of treatment.1

In 2008, the General Medical Council (GMC) published guidelines outlining the sharing of information with patients and the process of consent.4 However, there are still inherent flaws in the conventional consenting process. In practice, the manner in which a management discussion is conducted is largely left to the discretion of the surgeon. Although this allows individualization of a discussion, it easily introduces personal bias and contributes to the lack of standardization of the consent process. Also an objective method of assessing patient competence and comprehension is usually omitted from the routine consent process. Finally, the consent is often limited to a discussion of treatment options, technical aspects of the procedure, and serious or commonly occurring risks, rather than discussing the entire surgical pathway.

A number of interventions have been designed to facilitate and improve the consent pathway. These include the taking of consent in the outpatient setting and increasing the time allocated for the consent process. Alternative information sources such as patient leaflets can also be beneficial, as the way that information is presented can often influence information transfer, with oral information often being retained poorly.5
The use of multimedia (MM) tools to aid consent may also be a useful tool in the consent process. Here we systematically review the use of MM technology to assist consent.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This systematic review was carried out with reference to the PRISMA statement6 to aid transparent and complete reporting of our study. A study protocol documenting keywords, inclusion criteria, and exclusion criteria was produced in advance.

sec.title: Literature Search
sec.p: A systematic review of the literature was performed using multiple electronic search engines, including PubMed, MEDLINE, Ovid, Embase, and Google Scholar. Search terms included “multimedia consent,” “interactive consent,” “electronic consent,” and “software consent.” The “related” function was used in PubMed to identify additional studies. References of the articles identified were also searched for by title and then subsequent abstract review. Relevant systematic reviews’ reference lists were examined, and any relevant articles encountered that were not retrieved in the original database search were also included. The last search date was February 28, 2011. Figure 1 summarizes search outcomes according to PRISMA guidelines.6

sec.title: Eligibility Criteria and Data Extraction
sec.p: All published studies reporting the use of MM programs to consent surgical patients were considered. The search was restricted only to articles published in English, but there were no limitations to date of publication or study type. Data were extracted on the author, date of publication, study design, and cohort. These were extracted independently by 2 reviewers (UE and JN).

sec.title: Study Selection
sec.p: Two reviewers (UE and JN) independently performed the database search and compared results. Relevant articles were retrieved, reviewed in full text, and merged. Discrepancies were discussed and mediated by a third author (AC).

sec.title: Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria
sec.p: To be included in data analysis, studies had to include the use of MM platform to improve the consent process in surgical or interventional procedures. Studies had to report on at least one of the outcome measures described in the next section. Studies were excluded when it was not possible to extract the necessary data from the published results. Authors were not contacted.

sec.title: Data Extraction and Outcome Measures
sec.p: The outcome measures reflect a broad consideration of all the factors we think are important in assessing the use MM in the consent process. Endpoints of interest included numerical scores for comprehension, preoperative and postoperative anxiety, patient satisfaction, postoperative pain and nausea, hospital admission length, and the length of the consent process.

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: Data were extracted from included studies and tabulated using Microsoft Excel. Because of the heterogeneity of methods and results the data are described, these could not be evaluated statistically.

sec.title: Literature Search
sec.p: The initial search identified 1277 citations. These were screened for relevance, and articles were included/excluded on the basis of predetermined criteria. A total of 31 articles were identified from this search. A further 4 articles were excluded from this list: 3 were not published in English, and 1 was a duplicate article. An additional 6 studies were retrieved from relevant systematic reviews.7-9 The final number of articles included in this systematic review was 33 (Figure 1).

sec.title: Study Characteristics
sec.p: A variety of MM technology was used across the 33 studies. This covered a diverse range of procedures. There were 14 bespoke interactive MM programs designed to run off an inpatient located computer; 1 linear program comprising 3D animations, text, and audio; 10 videos; 2 remotely accessed Internet-based interactive patient pathways; 2 interactive CD/DVDs; 2 Microsoft PowerPoint presentations with embedded videos and graphics; a computed tomography–image based anatomical 3D reconstruction; and Adobe Photoshop–edited patient images (Table 1). Wanzer et al10 and Chantry et al11 consented for surgical/endoscopic procedures in pediatric patients, and therefore, consent was gained from the legal guardian/parent by proxy. There were 19 randomized controlled trials (RCTs), 4 nonrandomized controlled trials (NRCTs), 7 prospective studies, 1 case series, 1 case report, and 1 large retrospective survey analysis. MM platforms crossed specialties and consented for various procedures, including prostatectomy, laparoscopic cholecystectomy, colonoscopy, circumcision, lumbar/spinal surgery, cardiac catheterization, parathyroidectomy, regional anesthesia, laparoscopic tubal ligation, ankle fracture surgery, arthroscopy, gastric band/bypass, hip replacement, endoscopy, cataract surgery, abdominal aortic aneurysm repair, oncology procedures, stem cell transplantation, arthrodesis, plantar fasciitis, laparoscopic urology, cholesteatoma surgery, and bone anchoring auricular prosthesis (Table 1).

caption.p: Summary of 33 Citations, Date of Publication (DoP), Study Type, Procedure, and Multimedia Platform

tr.td: Interactive password-protected patient pathway/information Web site
Interactive password-protected patient pathway/information Web site

fn.p: Abbreviations: RCT, randomized controlled trial; Rad., radical; NRCT, nonrandomized controlled trial; Lap., laparoscopic; AAA, abdominal aortic aneurysm; DVD, digital versatile disc; CD, compact disc; CT, computed tomography.

fn.label: a
fn.p: The oncology procedures specified by the authors were breast (26%), gastrointestinal (62%), and other (12%).

fn.label: b
fn.p: This retrospective analysis [j2] was subdivided into 3 separate procedures.

sec.title: Outcome Measures
sec.p: Parameters of interest were age, educational level, comprehension/understanding, anxiety, length of MM intervention time, and patient satisfaction. Reporting of demographic information was variable with 4 articles not providing information on age and 18 articles not supplying adequate information on educational level. None of the 33 articles reviewed provided complete data on endpoints of interest.

Of the 33 articles, 22 tested patient comprehension postintervention, 12 assessed anxiety, and all but 4 articles provided a measure of patient satisfaction. There was a discrepancy between the assessment tools used in the included studies. Therefore in the results, we have stratified educational level into “up to and including high school” and “above high school.” All studies used a unique comprehension assessment tool, some of which included individual modular comprehension scores.

A variety of anxiety assessment methods were used. This involved a preoperative questionnaire based on a Visual Assessment Score, Straight-Trait Anxiety Index, Likert-Point Scale, or modified versions of the aforementioned. It was not possible to extrapolate anxiety results from Jlala et al20 in this manner; we therefore, presented the results as a proportion of subjects recorded as having “high anxiety.”
Patient satisfaction was recorded as the percentage of subjects in the intervention group who rated the consent process as “good” or “very good,” or “satisfied” or “very satisfied.”

sec.title: Cohort Characteristics
sec.p: The average age across all 19 RCTs was 48.7. Deyo et al17 had the largest study size (n = 393) and Migden et al26 had the smallest (n = 11). The standard and MM consent groups were similarly matched in educational level. Thirteen of the 18 RCTs disclosed information on educational level, although Cornoiu et al12 only provided overall averages of maximum educational grade achieved. The mean percentages of subjects with an educational level above high school in the control and interventional groups were 41% and 35%, respectively.

There were 4 NRCTs, with an average age of 47.6. Yeh et al31 had the largest study size (n = 66) and Eggers et al30 the smallest (n = 40). Yeh et al31 was the only NRCT that offered information on educational level, this was relatively equal between the 2 groups (33% of the control group vs 27% of MM group were educated beyond high school level).

The average age across the 7 prospective studies in this review was 57. Kessler et al33 had the largest study size (n = 257) and Berman et al34 the smallest (n = 12). Of the 7 studies, 2 provided information on educational level, with an average of 43.5% of participants educated beyond high school level.

Morris and Rothera41 and Morris and Van Wijhe40 published a case report (n = 1) and a case series (n = 3), respectively, with no further patient demographics specified. Sobel and Popp42 published a retrospective survey analysis (n = 2423).

sec.title: Comprehension
sec.p: Of the 33 studies in this review, 22 assessed patient comprehension (15 RCTs, 4 NRCTs, and 3 prospective studies; Table 2). Bollschweiler et al14 assessed patients’ self-perception of how well they understood the information provided. Yeh et al31 assessed self-efficacy following hip surgery. We took the time required to achieve self-efficacy as a reflection of comprehension of a MM consent package, as it indicates that rehabilitation goals were better understood. The remaining 20 studies directly assessed comprehension by means of questionnaires designed to test knowledge gain and retention of information conveyed by MM consent programs.

tr.td: Guidance from professional medical educators. Evaluated through several revisions
Pretool posttool (day of surgery), 6 weeks postoperation
8-item self reported perception of understanding questionnaire
Designed by team of surgeons unaware of content of DVD
Two independent assessments of patient responses to focused questions
Modified Deaconess Informed Consent Comprehension Test
Reviewed by 5 endoscopists. Pilot-tested on 50 endoscopy patients
Questions determined by results of patient focus groups

fn.p: Abbreviations: Lap., laparoscopic; PP, PowerPoint; DVD, digital versatile disc; N/A, not applicable; Prog, program; T/F, true/false; AAA, abdominal aortic aneurysm; MCQ, multiple choice questionnaire; Y/N/U, yes/no/unsure; T/F/U, true/false/unsure; CVI, content validity index.

fn.label: a
fn.p: An improvement in comprehension was accepted as a significant higher comprehension score in the MM group compared with the control in at least one aspect of the information conveyed, for example, operative risk. Where there was more than one aspect of comprehension that was significantly higher, the highest P value is given.

fn.label: b
fn.p: “Tool” pertains to the MM consent process.

fn.label: c
fn.p: Of the 20 questions, 5 were not T/F, but followed a similar 2-option format.

sec.p: Of the 22 studies, 16 demonstrated statistically significant improvements in comprehension in the MM group in at least one aspect of the information conveyed, for example, operative risk, postoperative recovery, alternative treatments, and so on. The remaining 6 studies reported no significant difference in comprehension between the groups. None of the studies demonstrated better understanding in the control group compared with the MM group.

Of the 22 studies, 21 assessed comprehension by means of a written questionnaire. Tait et al18 assessed comprehension by reviewing transcribed patient responses to questions pertaining to the operation following exposure to the MM tool.

Only 3 of the 22 used comprehension tools based on modified versions of previously validated assessments. Tait et al18 adapted the Modified Deaconess Informed Comprehension Tests, Yeh et al31 validated their own questionnaire with the Content Validity Index, and Berman et al34 used the Modified Decisional Conflict Scale. The remaining 19 studies did not specify whether validation took place, although 5 studies involved expert review or pilot testing. The questionnaire used by Cornoiu et al12 involved review by professional medical educators and several revisions. In the study by Agre et al,21 the assessment tool was reviewed by five endoscopists and then pilot tested on 50 patients following endoscopy. The questionnaires used in the 2 studies by Rossi et al24,25 were both pilot tested on 5 subjects, and the questionnaire developed in the study by Beischer et al38 was based on the results of a patient focus group.

sec.title: Anxiety
sec.p: Of the 33 studies in this review, 12 measured anxiety, of which 10 were RCTs and 2 NRCTs. Of the 12 studies, 11 used unmodified validated anxiety surveys (Table 3). The anxiety survey in the study by Shaw et al16 incorporated 4 questions derived from the Hospital and Depression Scale (HADS) and 8 questions developed by the authors that were procedure specific.

tr.td: Interactive password-protected patient pathway/information Web site
Pretool, posttool, preoperation (2 weeks posttool), postoperation (within 8 hours)
Pretool, immediately posttool, immediately preoperation (several weeks posttool)

fn.p: Abbreviations: Lap., laparoscopic; PP, PowerPoint; Prog, Program; NS, not significant; STAI, State-Trait Anxiety Index; VAS, visual analog score; KASA, knowledge and skills acquisition; HADS, Hospital and Depression Scale; APAIS, Amsterdam Pre-operative Anxiety Scale and Information Scale.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Significance of difference in anxiety scores across multimedia and control groups.

fn.label: b
fn.p: “Tool” pertains to the multimedia consent process.

sec.p: Of the 12 studies, 5 measured anxiety prior to the MM consent process, and all 12 studies measured anxiety shortly after, of which 6 were shortly before surgical intervention. Except for the study by Eggers et al,30 all studies showed a reduction in posttool anxiety in the MM group. Of these, only 3 studies demonstrated a statistically significant difference. The remaining 9 studies showed no significant difference in anxiety between groups.

sec.title: Satisfaction
sec.p: Of the 33 studies in this review, 26 measured patient satisfaction with the MM consent process (Table 4). Sahai et al39 used the validated Client Satisfaction Questionnaire (CSQ-8), whereas the remaining 32 studies used a variety of custom satisfaction surveys. Shaw et al16 demonstrated a Cronbach’s α score of .80. The remaining studies did not disclose data on validity. The results of the satisfaction surveys across all 33 studies were very high.

caption.p: Summary of Method of Satisfaction Measure

tr.td: Interactive password-protected patient pathway/information Web site
Interactive password-protected patient pathway/information Web site

fn.p: Abbreviations: VAS, visual analog score; DVD, digital versatile disc; CD, compact disc; Y/N, yes/no; Y/N/U, yes/no/unsure; CSQ-8, Client Satisfaction Questionnaire.

fn.label: a
fn.p: The authors did not provide any further information on how satisfaction was measured.

sec.title: Completion Time
sec.p: Of the 32 studies in this review, 13 provided data on the completion time for the MM consent process, and 2 of the 13 studies also provided data on the standard consent process time (Table 5). Gyomber et al13 revealed a standard consent (SC) time of 20 minutes and an MM time of 18 minutes. Conversely, Migden et al26 demonstrated a slightly shorter SC time compared with MM; 5 minutes 31 seconds versus 6 minutes 11 seconds, respectively. The mean MM completion time was 14 minutes 55 seconds.

caption.p: Mean Completion Time of Consent Process

tr.td: Interactive password-protected patient pathway/information Web site

fn.p: Abbreviations: DoP, date of publication; RCT, randomized controlled trial; PP, PowerPoint; DVD, digital versatile disc; N/A, not applicable; NRCT, nonrandomized controlled trial.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This review evaluates the use of MM to consent patients for interventional procedures. A total of 33 studies assessing the role of MM in consent where indentified. The methodology was diverse and reflected in the heterogeneity of our results. A number of outcome variables were assessed, including comprehension, satisfaction, and anxiety. In many cases, the tools used to measure endpoints were not validated or standardized. This led to difficulty in assessing the results, for example, a value representing comprehension in one trial does not correspond to others. The lack of standardized assessment of outcomes is partly because of an absence of validated tools in the literature. Despite the heterogeneity of the results, a number of themes are recurrent. These are discussed here.

Of the 33 studies, 22 assessed patient comprehension. This was achieved through internally produced questionnaires. Only 3 studies had their questionnaires independently reviewed by experts. This lack of standardization meant that it was difficult to evaluate the results statistically. Most studies declare an overall improvement in comprehension with the use of MM, 73.7% of relevant studies achieving statistical significance. One trial assessing the use of an interactive program in third molar surgery produced a lower comprehension score in the MM compared with the SC (81% vs 87%).29 This contrasts other comprehension-based studies reviewed and also another third molar surgery trial (73% MM vs 40% SC, significance not specified).27

Although comprehension is pivotal to informed consent, there is an absence of a validated tool in current practice. There are a number of preliminary tools in the literature, these include the Deaconess Informed Consent Comprehension Test (DICCT), the Quality of Informed Consent (QuIC) questionnaire as well as modified Cloze testing. None have been validated beyond preliminary testing.

In view of the above, it is important to explore whether the lack of a validated standardized consent comprehension tool is a failure of current surgical practice, and it raises a number of key questions:

list-item.p: Should a standardized consent comprehension tool be developed for every surgical procedure, including low-risk intervention?
What level of comprehension is acceptable for informed consent (“pass mark”) and in view of the lack of international consensus, how should this be decided?

sec.p: Patient satisfaction was reported in 75% of the studies assessed. Again, there was a high level of heterogeneity. Satisfaction was poorly defined by studies, it was difficult to determine whether satisfaction was a reflection of MM usability or a reflection of improved understanding of the consent process. Subjective and objective tools were used. It is difficult to ascertain whether high patient satisfaction correlates with a greater understanding of the intervention or merely reflect usability.

A total of 12 trials assessed anxiety. Of these, 7 reported a decrease in anxiety in the MM group (2 statistically significant). Conversely, 3 studies showed an increase in patient anxiety in the MM group (none significant). The remaining study declared no statistical difference. The heterogeneity of our results reflects the published literature where similar reviews and studies have revealed a general reduction in patient anxiety following provision of additional information in the consent process.

Of the 3 studies in our review that demonstrated significant reductions in anxiety in the MM group, 2 also demonstrated significant improvements in comprehension.22,28 This finding is supported by Bergers Uncertainty Reduction Theory which stipulates that communication is a key element in reducing uncertainty in initial encounters between strangers.10,43,44 Although this theory was not developed from a clinical patient–doctor perspective, it does highlight that an increase in uncertainty will cause an increase in information-seeking behavior. Whether this was displayed in response to uncertainty or inadequacy of information in the consent process was not possible to determine from the studies in our review.

There was a paucity of both preoperative and postoperative anxiety measures in the trials reviewed. This indicates that the effects of an MM consent program on patients expectation and perceptions along the entire length of the surgical pathway has not been assessed fully.

Two of the 33 studies obtained informed consent from parents or guardians.11,16 Although neither study showed any difference in anxiety or comprehension between standard consent and MM groups, the high satisfaction scores indicates that using MM in “consent by proxy” is a feasible option.

Overall, this review suggests that the use of MM as an adjunct to conventional consent appears to improve patient comprehension. This is possibly related to the audiovisual stimulatory cues MM programs provide in comparison with standard consent as well as allowing the patient the time, comfort, and control to consolidate and reexplore the information provided.

Multimedia leads to high patient satisfaction in terms of feasibility, ease of use, and availability of information. There is no conclusive evidence demonstrating a significant reduction in preoperative anxiety.

A recurring theme is the lack of a standardized method of obtaining informed consent. The standard consent process invariably involved a discussion with a surgeon and, in many circumstances, supplemented with information sheets. The level of detail and breadth of discussion was subject to individual preference and local policy. The stark variety in risk disclosure and comprehension assessment in obtaining informed consent has been documented in the literature.45

Multimedia may have a role to play in improving patient comprehension and supplementing the time constraints of the patient–doctor encounter. Patients will always want a human element to their care and ultimately the patient–doctor relationship will remain focal for questions and worries. Consent is not currently taught at undergraduate or postgraduate level, and this may be a means of introducing standardization.

Further work is required to establish a validated and standardized method of obtaining informed consent and assessing patient comprehension before the use of MM in surgical consent can be fully assessed.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The authors received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
